Let me start by saying this is not a bad game, but rather it is just not my type of game. I enjoy the concept presented here but it really did have too much in common with Munchkin (open trading leads to a lot of kingmaking, especially with the ability to give straight up victory points, and the ability to lock people down from earning public objectives can really shut them down altogether) and Risk (build armies and take territories, which determine your income which give you actions/ships to go take more territories).

There was also a lot of downtime between turns which led to not only me getting impatient, but also me constantly forgetting and missing triggers (or planet activations) that happened on my turn (and there are dozens).

I highly recommend anyone given the opportunity to try this to take it, as it is a great way to see if this is a game for you before buying it. But I recommend trying your first game with four to limit the time investment you have to make into it.

Ah, Twilight Imperium, the "crown jewel" of board gaming that doubles as a sleep study for those brave—or foolish—enough to play it. If you’ve ever thought, “What if we turned an entire week of galactic Senate meetings into a board game?” then congratulations, you’re the exact target audience for this interstellar time sink.

Let’s talk about setup: Twilight Imperium doesn’t just ask for your time; it demands your soul. Before you even start playing, you’ll spend an hour assembling a map that looks like it was designed by a toddler with a space obsession and no sense of balance. And good luck explaining the rules to new players, because nothing screams "welcome to the game" like a three-hour TED Talk on trade agreements and wormhole navigation.

The gameplay? Oh, it’s so simple—if you’re a 4D chess-playing android with a spreadsheet for a brain. You’ll juggle a baffling array of systems, from combat to politics to economics, all while trying to figure out why your neighbor is hoarding trade goods like they’re prepping for an intergalactic apocalypse. And don’t even get me started on the infamous negotiation phase, where you’ll watch grown adults argue about space treaties like they’re auditioning for Star Wars: The Bureaucracy Edition.

Of course, this all culminates in battles that should feel epic but mostly boil down to rolling a fistful of dice and praying the RNG gods take pity on you. Want to conquer your rival’s planets? Too bad—hope you enjoy staring at your plastic fleet while everyone else debates a Senate resolution about universal healthcare for space turtles.

But the true horror of Twilight Imperium is its runtime. A single game can stretch anywhere from 8 to 12 hours, which is roughly the time it takes to binge-watch an entire season of The Expanse—and trust me, The Expanse is way more fun. By hour six, you’ll question not just your decision to play, but your very existence. Who are you? What is life? Why does winning the galactic throne require sacrificing an entire day?

The cherry on top? The ending. After all those hours, the game often concludes with someone sneakily achieving an obscure objective while the rest of the table stares in stunned silence. No fanfare, no applause—just a collective groan as everyone realizes they wasted their Saturday on glorified space Sudoku.

So, if you’re looking for a game that devours your free time, tests your friendships, and leaves you emotionally drained, Twilight Imperium has got you covered. Everyone else? Maybe stick to Catan and enjoy finishing a game before you hit retirement age.

Likely a 4, but the amount of 10s baffles me so I rated it a 1. Notice how a majority of the reviewers never include this in their top 100s. Well there's a reason for that. Out of the 500+ games I played this feels belongs at the bottom. Honestly, one of the worst designed games I've played. To start I enjoy long games when they are fun, but the playtime was severely inflated (over 14 hours with the PoK expansion in a 5 player game), with a worse than lackluster experience. It combines the randomness of dice with unrestricted negotiation, encouraging the worst game mechanics of all time - Kingmaking and player elimination. To be clear player eliminatiom didn't happen in our game, but the fact the game is designed to promote it in a day long experience is awful. Luck based games can certainly be fun and I do enjoy them, but if I could play about 12 of them in the timespan I could have played this once, I would have recieved significantly enjoyment out of it.

The theme of the game (space battles) also doesn't match the mechanics (random goal draws and a point race?). This game is more about initial exploration and squatting in your space sectors, more than an immersed epic battle. There is no/limited catch up mechanic to prevent unlucky rolls nor kingmaking to allow for a more holistic and enjoyable group experience. Sure one person might be happy about the whole experience, but the rest of the group feels like they just wasted half of their weekend. My sentiments on the game match 4 out of the 5 people that played it in pur session. The personality of the other is more geared towards lore, which I'll admit that is the one thing this game has going it, but I personally enjoy mechanical sound games more.

Also I enjoy heavy games, this is not that by any means. This game is an over abundance of rules with little substance. Many that don't really matter when comes down to a bunch of uninteresting dice rolls that everyone is eagerly waiting to be done. I get the feeling that this game makes people they are playing a big complex game, but in actualuality the fuzzy logic and probability predictions have little to do with the end result. The luck mitigation mostly comes from lucky card draws. More than half of the cards benefits are polictal effects, which is unless considering our uninteresting our political phases were. So there was no real luck mitigation designed into a game of chance. The strategy is severely lacking and comes down negotiability, chance, alliance symbiosis, and player aggression.

This game doesn't deserve to be in the top 100 let alone the top ten, in my opinion. However the great thing about society is just one person's opinion doesn't matter and the diversity of interests and passion is what makes our gaming community so expansive and beautiful. So for me I hated TI4, but I can completely understand why some people love it. I normally wouldn't take the time to write such a long and scathering review, but I feel like they were too many deceptive reviews, for people with interests like mine, and I wanted to give my hot take.

It's just waaaay too long. It's a game of negotiation, dice and random card draws (read ameritrash) with some great ideas, fun moments and hours upon hours of boredom. The game has so much going on and there are elements of euro strategy, but at the end of 10+ hours it's all decided by random chance. I feel like the game lacks soul and tries to spread itself too thin. It's trying to please everyone and obviously it's working for a lot of people, but not for me. I like the strategy actions (though leadership is OP) and their secondary follow actions, I like the command tokens and the puzzle of managing them well, but all the rest felt too random for me. I don't even think the dice were that much of a problem (though I think 10 sided dice are just fundamentally wrong), it's more about the objectives. It's fun to have such wildly different races, but it also means that by random chance someone can end up with secret objectives they complete on turn 1 and others with completely impossible ones, just by chance. This also means that the public objectives are much easier for some and beyond that, the objectives are so bland so that they could be somewhat possible for every race. This is the only thing the players are aiming for, pretty much the only way to get points, and they're boring and very unbalanced. The tier 2 cards are also just more expensive copies of the tier 1 cards, meaning that if someone has an advantage for one of them, they can easily get 2 more points in the later half of the game, leading to a massive 3 point swing. The diplomacy phase didn't really work for me either, most of the laws and directives are simpky not impactful enough and when they are, negotiation is a limited option since most people will have a strong opinion, so it's all about who has the most influence. That's also a very boring resource, in the first parts if the game it's only used for the effect of 1 strategy card and for the rest of the game it's only used on that and votes. Why even have it when there's nothing to do with it? The technologies are all good and well done, but they barely change between games and players, so everyone will end up with mostly the same stuff.

If you're going to have a game with a lot of randomness, why does it take so infinitely long to play? If you're going to have an epic game, why make it a race to points and why limit the amount of long term strategy to only technology and random, non-impactful laws? You can't even save up resources between rounds! So yeah, it's not for me, and compounded upon that it takes so long, so no I probably won't ever play again, hence the rating.

Epic is “History of the World” - 3000 years of civilisation (or “Outreach” which takes 3000 years and adds billions of people, a third of the galaxy and a 16 hour run time.)

Yet again it finished before it really got going (this time we didn’t even reveal all of the 1vp public victory conditions!) I don’t want to invest on a 10 turn strategy if the game is over after 5 and the competition to rule the galaxy turns out to be an episode of Krypton Factor; and I don’t want to spend 5+ hours on a VP chase of building some structures that could be complete on turn 2 (and only the “1 public vp per turn” limit keeps the game going.)

Everywhere I look is disappointment.

A lot of techs to research but I only researched 2, used the first to research the second and the second to build a ship that had no purpose because the game was over before it moved. I often complain that the best techs in a game are pointless because game is over before you can exploit them but that was ridiculous.

Not that many systems to visit but barely any battles in the game.

No economy to build - all the planets are worth whatever (and couldn’t they have sorted out a consistent symbol for trade goods on the planet and the counters?)

Commodities/trade goods - what was that all about?

Agendas and promises - I don’t think finding a easy way to give the eventual winner a free 4 vp (in a 10 vp game) really helped, plus agendas feel so tacked on. Perhaps some groups can make this bit the highlight of the game, I’d rather it just went away.

Contrary to other comments here I actually liked the strong mechanics. The strategy cards, following others' actions and managing your command tokens in different pools. Good euro mechanics in the core of the game.

That said, for a space epic the game is almost void of epic moments. Hardly combat in the game as combat does not bring you points.

Because the artificially limited scoring makes you crawl for only a point per round it’s impossible to make a big epic clash and end up with a dramatic move, lots of points and thus epic rounds of victory and defeat. Instead the most exciting moment is topdecking secret objectives as some of them give you free points instantly while the others demand a full three round set up to achieve.

The game desperately needs some home brewed variants, like opening up more goals per round and allowing to score multiple objectives per round.

Voting for agendas between play rounds is a great idea, but implemented in a horribly fiddly way. One of the fiddliest rule segments in any game. Not only are you voting, but you have different amount of votes per player. Sounds awesome until you realise someone first gives 7 votes leaving them 4 for the next agenda, other player then votes 11 leaving them 15, the third player votes... wait now, how many did you have left again and what’s the total sum for and against? The agenda phase is probably way better in a digital platform and upkeep. I could even do all the artificial math if the agendas were important to the game... but in our play all this hoopla was for some laws that made zero difference during the game or for the win. Lackluster waste of time.

Twilight Imperium: Fourth Edition is an amazing game - in theory. In practice, it is a game that heavily relies on a veil of majestic wonder and awe at its perceived grandeur. Now, I love this game and I hope that it inspires countless others like it, but I simply can't suggest anyone to pick it up without knowing what you're getting into.

The Good
+ TI4 is, without a doubt, eye catching! Its this massive box with wonderful art of galactic scale, drawing from the ideas of cult sci-fi classics. Inside is like a goody bag of plastic ships and cardboard tiles to form your very own galaxy.
+ If you have a game group of 5+ friends who are hardcore board game players, there are few games that can take as much dedication as TI4. Most games will run for a minimum of 6 hours, sometimes even going a full day if you have 8 people at the table.
+ Strategy wise, TI4 allows for a wide-range of options for your chosen faction/civilization. Will you be warmongers, political diplomats, a kingmaker? There are countless ways you run your empire in the pursuit of victory. But, that brings up my first major issue with TI4...

The Bad
- Strategy wise, nothing matters to TI4 except Victory Points. If you can't score an objective by the end of the round, you have simply wasted your time. To really get into this point, you have to understand that the main method of earning VP is objectives which are predetermined goals the game lays out for you. These are not options, these are not request - these are demands that the game enforces on the players.
- Once this veil is pulled back, you will quickly learn that TI4 is not a civilization-builder: it's a VP engine-builder. You're one and only goal is to earn VP and to defend yourself.
- Offensive combat is not only frowned upon, but actively punished. You rarely will ever earn VP for direct combat and, worse yet, will often lose a few ships no matter what due to the game's dice combat. This creates a double-deficit for engaging in war. You don't earn VP, thus putting you behind, and you lose valuable resources.
- The last point I'll bring up is the imbalance of factions. Most factions are "okay" and can have a decent shot at winning. The main issue lies in just a few factions being arguably unplayable if the rest of the table knows what they are doing. The biggest victims of this are the Winnu (core game) and Arborec

The most extra board game. Will absolutely be the peak of the hobby, to some people. Some scatterbrained thoughts on this beast:

- My original thoughts on TI4 were mostly on the negative side, but it turns out my main complaint (too many special abilities to remember) was resolved by removing the expansion. The base game definitely has enough as-is if you’re the type of person who only plays this maybe once a year, like me. With the expansion removed, TI4 reveals itself to be a massive but manageable experience, and a very exciting event game. I think the expansion is maybe more for people who have played this like 5+ times and want to spice things up a bit.

- The action selection is great. I love how you need to balance your tactics and strategy token pools so that you can eke the most out of every round. Gauging what actions you need to prepare for is a great, fuzzy puzzle to figure out. The actions themselves are all useful and all powerful in certain scenarios, and preparing yourself for those scenarios is a lot of fun. The grand strategy that comes out of this aspect is awesome.

- The political side of the game eludes me. It's absolutely there, and the council phase is a ton of fun, but the wider negotiation that needs to happen in the rest of the game is hard to parse, since it's never clear to me what my opponents need. That unknowability (which admittedly is there becuase of my lack of experience with the game) makes negotiations quick and scary. Which is fun, but also makes it so that I don't know how to use it correctly as one of my tools to win the game. I have weird feelings about the negotiation elements, needless to say! I'm ultimately happy that the game is so politics-forward, and I kind of love it for that, but it's just weird in the wider context of trying to understand what your opponents need. Which, I mean, sometimes it doesn’t matter in negotiation games if you don't know what opponents need, but so much of the game feels zero-sum that it just feels like some deals are probably absolutely terrible for you and you don't know which ones they are. I'm sure I'll have more solid thoughts on this on future plays.

- The action cards add some great fuzziness to the game, but some of them are just straight BS, haha. It's fun, but also can be grueling in a big ol' strategy game that takes 5-8 hours.

- The puzzle of figuring out how to fulfill the various objectives that give you points is really satisfying, but I think their implementation is frustrating. I didn't love the feeling of "I finished all the objectives I could this round, now what do I do?" and having pretty much no way to stop others from fulfilling theirs. I get why the game is built around these objectives, and I get that there ARE other things you can do other than fulfilling them, but I still didn't love the way that they worked. And sometimes objectives come up (or end up in your hand) that are dirt-simple for others to get, but take a ton of work for you. It's not meant to be fair, but it can be frustrating in a game that (again) takes 5-8 hours to play.

Disclaimer: I have played third edition a lot. There were a few years while I was a university student in which I played it at least once a month. I've even chained two games in a row. I am very familiar with the meta game, and so is my group. I haven't played TI4 nearly as much, but have gotten a handful of games in.

TI4 streamlines TI3 in ways I don't like. TI3 allowed for large point swings, which meant players end game score differences could be high, but the game still felt close, because multiple players could still be a few moves away form pulling a swing themselves.

TI4 doesn't have point swings, which means players scores will end up clumped together. But it also means TI3's issues, this is, rewarding encroaching playstyles and analysis paralysis, are present even more. It rewards bashing the leader too. It's got objectively good mechanical improvements, like the tech tree, but these don't compensate for how the changes overall affect the meta game.

Is third edition perfect? Certainly not. But I much rather loose with a huge point difference, knowing I did my best, than play a game that's twice as long. I've been able to play TI3 in under an hour per player, without including set up and clean up. To put it into numbers, last TI4 game I played lasted two and a half hours per player because nobody could pull ahead.

With all that said, if you've got a stable gaming group with which to play this, and all of them are new to the TI games, the journey I had with mine from total newbies to veterans was wild. I've got a lot of precious memories tied to this saga I wouldn't trade them for anything in the world. But I also will try to stay as far from TI4 as I possibly can.

The hunt for objective points is a great mechanic over needing to take opponents homeworld or hold territory till the final round (build up to big round 9 battle is my main complaint with Eclipse). And while there’s interesting tech and race abilities, it doesn’t seem to become so complex that you can’t pretty easily glance at opponent’s amassed units and know how they will roll (long range space cannons are a bit tiresome, since they can be hiding amid a pile of plastic in adjacent hexes you’re not paying attention to - I would eliminate that tech). The Puerto Rico mechanism works well, although having clockwise order for selecting them seems bad design (you will benefit by having a player to your right that wants to keep taking Political). I think they should be selected based on previous round’s turn order, and the game would benefit by having a turn order track with player counters, where you reorder them after each strategy phase, and indicate when a player has passed.

The agenda voting is not well designed, and voting in games like AGoT and Lannister is much better. Turn-based voting, election votes (you have to select a player), the uncertainty of whether the 2nd agenda will matter, and that the agenda deck varies wildly from crippling to one player to no one gives one crap, combine to create a big unfun waste of time. I would definitely house rule this by going through the deck and only keeping the for/against agendas (and only those that seem at least conditionally interesting), flip only 1 agenda card each round, and make voting simultaneous: everyone just goes thumbs up or thumbs down at the same time, commiting all their planets’ influence towards their up/down vote. You can still negotiate before that, but once negotiating is done, everyone puts out their thumb at the same time.

I would also house-rule removing the secret objective cap. I really like not knowing what players might be going after, but since you can’t score more than 2 of them at most a round (1 during status phase, and 1 during action phase if you’re lucky enough to draw one of those), I don’t really see any reason to have a hard cap of 3 (incomplete in hand + scored on the table). The game is long enough without this rule preventing it from coming to a quicker exciting conclusion.

Lastly, a more minor graphic issue: I wish the planet art was much more functional, like solid colors of their trait, and then a big science symbol on the planet’s face. With tons of plastic on the board, the small science and trait symbols get completely covered.

Comments: Twilight Imperium: Fourth Edition is a strategy game about area influence, dice rolling, follow actions, grid movement, tech trees, variable set up and players powers, voting, etc. It has a LOT of things going on.

Twilight Imperium: Fourth Edition is a monster of a game in many ways: it is big (350+ miniatures, 400+ cards), sprawling, long, complex (but not all that much), and it has many, many moving parts.

TI4 shares the role selection mechanic that is used in games like Puerto Rico and Race for the Galaxy, in which you choose a role, that will give you a major action and the others can "follow" the same role, but doing some minor action. To follow a role you spend Strategy tokens. There are 8 roles in the game: Initiative, Diplomacy, Politics, Logistics, Trade, Warfare, Technology, Imperial.

Every round, the players will choose a role to do, and the choosing order will go from the player that took Initiative in the last round (and the player can't choose Initiative two times in a row). The players choose a role in clockwise order, beginning with the one that took the Initiative role last round. But after this, the order of play will follow the order of the numbers on the roles. The players can activate the role anytime during his turn, and once he does it, the major action will happen, then every other player will be able to do the minor action of the role by paying one Strategy token (and usually will be necessary to spend resources also) - the Initiative role doesn't have a major action, it allows, however, to the player that selected it to use all the minor roles without spending Strategy tokens (and, of course, the player will be the first to select a role in the next round).

Also, the players will have a number of Command tokens, and they can be used, each at a time, to activate a hex (system) in the board, and is only possible to activate a hex once for round (the Warfare role allows for the possibility to activate the same hex twice). You activate a hex in order, usually, to build units (ships, ground forces, docks, PSDs) or to move units (then you place the Command token in the hex to where the ships will move).

The game revolves around these things: actions of the roles and actions (activations) made by the Command tokens. Basically the roles serve for: Initiative (be the first to act), Diplomacy (stop someone from attacking you), Politics (bring an event for voting, also to gain Action cards), Logistics (to gain tokens, that you can put in the Command, Strategy and/or Fleet Supply), Trade (gain resources, also allows for trade deals to be made, or to break all of them), Warfare (to activate twice the same system), Technology (to discover new technologies), Imperial (score points).

Twilight Imperium: Fourth Edition is very rich in options, and not a lonesome game, as everyone pays attention to the others, trying to take advantage of the minor action of the roles, struggling to get the timming of actions right (like waiting to activate rolls when you know some other players won't be able to do the minor action), and, of course, because it is a game of conquest, thus it is only a matter of time before the battles start to happen, especially for Mecatol (the capital center of the board), since the use of the Imperial cards have a boost to those holding Mecatol, as well as being able to fulfill some particular objectives.

Twilight Imperium: Fourth Edition it is a game that puts players face to face, brawling for the same spaces, the same actions, building fleets and technologies in order to attack the planets of others. And also of politics, since you can make deals with the other races, vote for events that will benefit some (or harm others). It is, also, a very long game, with many hours of playing time, that definitely won't fit the tastes, time or even table of most players, but for those that do, it is a treat.
Twilight Imperium is a thematic, deep, and rich experience that's absurd play length will likely keep all but the most hardcore fans from engaging with it time and time again.

My previous experience
I have previously owned and played TI3 a handfull of times and I had mixed feelings about it. There were so many little things in the base version that I didn't like. Sure most where later fixed with the expansions. In TI4 you get a definitive version of everything.

Why TI4 is better
TI4 is just a much better game because it fixes all issues I had with TI3 and streamlines a lot. I like the new strategy cards, how trading works, the overhauled technology tree. I didn't like Distant Suns or the Leaders so I don't miss them at all.

More stuff I like
I like getting the 17 races with 2 racial techs, the flagships and promissory notes in the box. The new insert isn't perfect but at least it is usable. The public and secret objectives also breaks up the traditional turtleing. And finally, I personally think the new artwork is fantastic and looks way more modern.

What I don't like
TI4 is streamlined but it is still a game that takes a long time to play and has a lot of rules that can be quite complicated for new players. Once you get into the second half of the game it will start to feel more and more like a slog.

Not for everybody
TI has never been a game for everybody and TI4 doesn't change that. It's still a long epic space war game where you roll dice to decide the outcome of battles and the luck of card draws has an impact on the game. It is still a game that will likely take a whole day and is difficult to get to the table.

Conclusion
For me personally, I like this version and I will keep it and try to get it to the table more often. It is the best epic space experience out there. And I think it's worth the money, if it's the type of game you like.

If you liked area control in the 4x variety, you would probably like - possibly love - this game. The theme is set in space which adds to the epic feeling of the game. The game is about building a mightier empire than your opponents. Mightier doesn't necessarily mean the largest one. Factors like technology, resources, influence or military power are important as well. You can achieve victory points through different tasks and the first player who has ten points wins.
Depending on your game group fighting isn't that important or comes rather towards the last part of the game. You will resolve a lot of issues through negotiations, trading, threats or military deterrence. The game is highly interactive.
On many levels the game is fantastic, but it is also extremely long. It's not for a game night but for a game day. It doesn't necessarily feel too long when you are playing it and the length even adds to the epic feeling. Sometimes players will take some time for their turns though, there definitely is some downtime. And the long playing time will make it hard for you to find several players which are willing to invest so many hours in a game and are availaibe at the same time.
If you have a few bad rounds at the beginning, e.g., because another player is attacking you mercilessly, it can happen that you don't have a realistic chance to win the game anymore although only half of it is over. In such situations the long playing time is not great.

While the earlier iterations (I played TI1 and TI3) are fun as well I definitely recommend to choose the fourth edition. It's way better than the previous editions.

"Capital Ships" and "Tech Progression"
----------------------- Capital Ships ---------------------------------
“If it looks heavy, it should feel heavy. ~ Heavy on it.“
All capital ships gain a shield this game:
- Flagships have 4 shield points.
- War Suns, Dreadnoughts, Carriers have 2 shield points.
- Cruisers have 1 shield point.

Flagships and Dreadnoughts roll 1 additional die each round in combat.
Local PDS participates in each round of combat instead of rolling space cannon before combat.

Use small cubes or markers to track each ships shield points.
When a capital ship gets hit put a shield marker next to it.
When a capital ship gets a hit beyond its shield points flip it over if it has sustain damage or destroy it like in the original rules.

When you would use an ability that repairs a ship during combat instead remove a shield marker if it is not flipped over. After combat remove all shield makers.

When you produce fighters or infantry you can produce 2 for one production point.
--------------------------- Tech Progression -----------------------------
“All your tech are belong to us.
You have no chance to survive make your tech. “ 
Every player starts their rounds with researching an extra tech.
On round 1 you can research tech with 0 prerequisites this way.
On round 2 you can research tech with 1 prerequisites or lower.
On round 3 you can research tech with 2 prerequisites or lower.
On round 4 you can research tech with 3 prerequisites or lower.
On round 5 and onwards you can research tech the another factions has already researched.
